label: a rdfs:label
definition: A definition SPLIT =|
evaluant: C (has_specified_input some (% and 'has role' some 'evaluant role)) and (realizes some ('evaluant role' and ('role of' some %))) SPLIT=|
analyte: C (has_specified_input some %) and (realizes some ('analyte role' and ('inheres in' some%)))
device: C (has_specified_input some %) and (realizes some (function and ('inheres in' some %))) SPLIT=|

label: method
definition: A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

label: gray matter tissue preparation
definition: Class of methods that are used to prepare the gray matter tissue of interest for application of other methods.

label: visualization method
definition: Class of methods that are used to make visible the objects of interest or physiological processes to the eye of the experimenter, unaided or using specific devices.

label: analysis method
definition: Class of methods that are used to process and interpret the data produced by measurements, as well as to infer patterns or regularities from data.

label: sterotaxic surgery
definition: Surgery performed according to the spatial (stereotactic) coordinates of the brain and spinal cord in a given species. These coordinates are calculated relative to a set of landmarks: bregma, lambda, and the interaural distance, and from a standard stereotaxic atlas.

label: basophilic stain method
definition: Class of histochemical methods where the dyes label the nucleic acids (RNA).

label: nissl method
definition: Histochemical method for labeling neurons. Application of basophilic dyes, such as Cresyl violet, Thionin and Toluidin Blue, to the brain tissue labels the nuclei of cell bodies of neurons, and of glia. These dyes bind preferentially to the RNA present in the cell, and the cell nuclei will be most stained because of the high presence of this nucleic acid.

label: hematoxilin and eosin method
definition: Histochemical method for labeling the neurons. Hematoxilin labels the cell bodies, and eosin the cytoplasm. It is the most common method used in clinical and research labs.

label: luxol fast blue method
definition: Histochemical method that stains in bluish color the myelin around axons.

label: golgi method
definition: Classical cytochemical method used for neurons labeling. The method is based on the absorbtion of silver nitrates into the neurons, staining them entirely in deep brown to black. The stain is taken up by only maximum of 10% of the neurons in a labeled tissue.

label: golgi-cox method
definition: Variant of the Golgi method that uses mercury salts instead of silver. The labeling process takes 2 weeks, but the method is considered as the most reliable method from all Golgi techniques.

label: rapid golgi method
definition: Modification of the Golgi method that is faster than Golgi-Cox method. In this method osmium is added to the silver precipitation.

label: golgi-kopsch method
definition: Modification of the Golgi method where osmium that is used in rapid Golgi method is replaced by formaldehyde.

label: timm-danschle method
definition: Based on the property of the sulphide silver to reduce the metals present in trace amounts in cells to the corresponding metal sulphide and silver. The latter will form grains. The application of different types of chelating factors results in the bleaching of cells, or the opposite. It is suited for visualization at the light and electron microscope of synapses.

label: kluver-barrera
definition: Extension of the Luxol Fast Blue method; the nuclei cell bodies are counterlabeled with cresyl violet or thionin.

label: cytochemical method
definition: Class of staining methods that label the component cells of a tissue of interest in detail.

label: direct immunohistochemistry
definition: Class of methods used to label peptides and proteins in tissues for interest using a single (primary) antibody.

label: indirect immunohistochemistry
definition: Class of methods used to label peptides and proteins in tissues of interest using a secondary antibody, which binds specifically to the primary, for signal amplification.

label: enzymatic histochemistry
definition: Class of methods that use enzymes of specific peptides and proteins. The result of interaction is labeled. Examples: Acetylcholinesterase, cytochrome oxidase.

label: immunohistochemistry for light microscopy
definition: Class of immunohistochemical methods which have their byproducts visible with the light microscope.

label: avidin-biotinylated HRP complex method
definition: Immunohistochemical method that uses horseradish peroxidase (HRP) for visualization with the light microscope, and biotin conjugated with secondary antibodies.

label: peroxidase-antiperoxidase method
definition: Immunohistochemical method that uses the peroxidase-antiperoxidase complex to recognize the secondary antibody. This conjugated complex interacts enzymatically with specific molecules (e.g. HRP and DAB) and the colored product can be visualized with light microscope.

label: immunohistochemistry for fluorescent microscopy
definition: Class of immunohistochemical methods for visualization with confocal microscope. These methods generally use two antibodies, and the fluorophore is conjugated with the second antibody.

label: single labeling fluoro-immunohistochemistry
definition: Immunohistochemical method that uses two antibodies to describe the localization of a single protein of interest, which can be visualized with the confocal microscope.

label: multiple labeling fluoro-immunohistochemistry
definition: Immunohistochemical methods that are used to describe the co-localization of multiple proteins of interest, which can be visualized with the confocal microscope. The primary antibodies should not cross-react with each other. The fluorophores need to have minimal overlapping excitation/emission spectra one relative to the other, and from the background.

label: double labeling fluoro-immunohistochemistry
definition: Immunohistochemical method that is used to describe the co-localization of two proteins of interest, which can be visualized with the confocal microscope. The primary antibodies should not cross-react with each other. The fluorophores need to have minimal overlapping excitation/emission spectra, one relative to the other as well as from that of the background. This method allows identification of four phenotypes of cells in the tissue of interest.

label: triple labeling fluoro-immunohistochemistry
definition: Immunohistochemical method that is used to describe the co-localization of three proteins of interest, which can be visualized with the confocal microscope. The primary antibody should not cross-react. The fluorophores need to have minimal overlapping excitation/emission spectra one relative to the other, and from the background. This method allows identification of nine phenotypes of cells in the tissue of interest.

label: lucifer yellow labeling
definition: Cytochemical method that uses Lucifer Yellow for morphological characterization of cells. The labeling is performed by filling the cell with this fluorescent dye. It can be used in conjuction with electrophysiological experiments, and for study of gap juctions and glial cells. It is also used as in tract tracing experiments.

label: immunohistochemistry for electron microscopy
definition: Immunohistochemical method similar to that for light microscopy, which is used to identify the antigen distribution into cell organelles. However, the slices for EM are very thin, they need to be better fixated, and the tissue has to be embedded in resin.

label: biocytin labeling
definition: Cytochemical method that uses biocytin for morphological characterization of cells. The labeling process is performed iontophoretically. The main advantages of this method are: the small size of the molecule, the molecule is (highly0 water soluble and it can be combinec with fluorescent markers. Biocytin can also be used as an anterograde tract-tracing stain.

label: autoradiographic labeling
definition: Class of tissue and nucleic acid labeling techniques that use radioactive isotopes as labels. The isotopes can be associated with ligands of the molecules of interest or included in them.

label: radioligand binding assay
definition: Tissue labeling technique using radioactively-labeled ligands to receptors of interest. The ligands need to have high specifity, high value of the ratio between the specific binding and the nonspecific one, and a high specific activity.

label: competition assay
definition: Pharmacological method used to screen an array of drugs for their ability to bind to the receptor of interest.

label: traditional PCR
definition: The original PCR method, where amplified PCR products are detected at the end of all cycles. The method can not provide quantitative measures, but semi-quantitative, as a ratio between the yielded signal vs. the known signal of known concentrations.

label: real-time PCR with DNA-binding dyes
definition: Real time PCR method using fluorescent dyes, which intercalate within the double-strand DNA and emits fluorescence. Multiplication of the double-strands increase the fluorescence. The dyes are not DNA-sequence specific.

label: real-time PCR with fluorescent primers
definition: Real time PCR method using fluorophores directly attached to target specific primers Each time the primer is used to synthesize a new DNA strand, fluorescence intensity will increase.

label: real-time PCR with fluorescent probes
definition: A very sensitive qt-PCR that uses two target specific primers (forward and reverse), and a probe. Because the primers are specific, this qt-PCR method is also very specific.

label: quantitative reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction
definition: A very sensitive rt-PCR method used for detection and measurement of RNA and mRNA.

label: one step quantitative reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction
definition: Both reverse transcription and qPCR are performed in one step in a single tube that contains the RNA, the reverse transcriptase and the DNA polymerase, and the other reverse transcription and the qPCR reagents.

label: two steps quantitative reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction
definition: qrt-PCR method that first creates the DNA (cDNA) from the provided RNA using a transcriptase. In the second step, 10%-20% of the produced cDNA is used as template for the qtPCR.

label: multiplex polymerase chain reaction
definition: PCR method that contains multiple primers, therefore it is used to detect and measure several genes simultaneously. It is used for gene coexpression in a single cell.

label: reverse transcriptase multiple polymerase chain reaction
definition: RT-PCR method for detection and measurement of several genes RNA.

label: patch-clamp cell attached mode
definition: Patch-clamp method where a small amount of suction is applied to the back of the pipette. This creates a very tight seal between pipette and membrane in such way that the ions will not flow between the membrane and the pipette. The single electric current will be that of a single opened ion channel in the patched membrane, and that will flow into the pipette. The resulting electrical current can be measured with an amplifier.

label: patch-clamp outside-out
definition: Variant of the patch-clamp method where the pipette is retracted and the attached membrane is exposed to the extracellular environment. It is used to studie the influence of different extratracellular molecules on the ion channels dynamics.

label: patch-clamp perforated patch
definition: Variant of the patch-clamp method where the glass pipette is continuous with the cell, but instead of applying suction in the cell-attached mode to transition into the whole-cell mode, a chemical (often an antibiotic) is applied from within the glass pipette, causing small perforations in the membrane. It is an intermediate between the cell-attached mode and whole-cell mode.

label: patch clamp whole cell
definition: Variant of the patch-clamp method where the glass pippete is continuous with the cytoplasm of the recorded cell. Used to measure the potentials and currents of the whole cell, and to inject different substances directly into the interior of the cell.

label: reporter genes method
definition: Class of methods for visualization and measurement of gene expression patterns using non-endogenous genes that are encoding for enzymes or fluorescent proteins whose expressions are controlled by the promoters for the gene of interest (different than the reporter gene). These genes are either directly controlled by the promoters of the genes of interest, or the DNA sequence of the reporter is fused with the DNA for the gene of interest (piggy-back), and both will be under the control of the promoter.

label: enyzme-linked immunosorbent assay
definition: Biochemical assay where a specific antibody binds to a protein of interest to mark the presence and measure the quantity of the protein in a sample.

label: chromatography
definition: Class of purification methods applied to a wide range of biomolecules.

label: gel filtration chromatography
definition: Purification method where the molecules of interest are run through through a column and are separated by their size.

label: affinity chromatography
definition: Purification method where the molecules are run through a matrix. Small molecules are fixed to the porous matrix to bind to molecules that may have a high affinity, such as a substrate binding to an enzyme.

label: antibody interference
definition: Purification method where the antibody is bound to the protein, which will interfere with its function.

label: matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization
definition: Technique used to bring the aminoacids sequence solution in gaseous state and charged. The sequence of interest is mixed with a UV-absorbing organic acid and dried on a metal slide. The sample is irradiated with a UV laser, causing the solution to go into the gas phase. The aminoacids sequence also becomes charged. This method precludes the mass spectometry technique.

label: collision induced dissociation
definition: Technique used to fragment proteins that have the mass to charge ratio identical, by bombarding with atoms (e.g. argon, nitrogen). The resulting fragments are the run through mass spectometers. The proteins are then reconstituted by overlapping the fragments.

label: kinase assay
definition: Technique used to determine whether a protein phosphorylates another protein (the substrate), by adding radioactive ATP. The radioactive phosphorus is transferred to the protein substrate, which is then immunoprecipitated. The purified phosphorylated protein is visualized using autoradiography.

label: luciferase assay
definition: Technique used to determine whether a protein can activate or repress the expression of a target gene and the amount of the gene product, by fusing the luciferase DNA to the regulatory region of the target protein DNA. However, it cannot determine if the protein directly interacts with the DNA or indirectly affects transcription by activating or repressing an intermediary protein that controls the transcription.

label: brightfield microscopy
definition: The most common and general form of light microscopy, using a simple or compound microscope. The visible light passes directly through or is reflected off a specimen.

label: darkfield microscopy
definition: This method uses oblique illuminating rays of light directed from the side so that only scattered light enters the objective lens. The objects that are transparent will appear dark, while those that reflect light will be very bright. Used in neuroanatomy for visualization of fiber tracts in Nissl stained slides. Also called darkground microscopy. Also known as Nomarski method.

label: infrared differential interference contrast microscopy
definition: Variant of the differentation interference contrast microscopy where the instead of light, infrared waves are used. This method is a combination of microscopy and spectrometry for infrared, which includes Fourier Transformation for transformation of IR into visible light.

label: voltage-sensitive dyes imaging
definition: Class of methods that use different molecules to visualize and measure variations of the electric potential in tissue, either in single cells or of cellular ensembles.

label: Fluorescent dyes imaging
definition: Class of voltage-sensitive dyes imaging methods where different synthetic fluorescent probes are used. They can be further subdivided in fast- and slow-sensitive methods, depending on whether they can detect fast vs slow electrical changes.

label: Permeable calcium-sensitive dyes imaging
definition: Class of calcium voltage-sensitive dyes imagining methods that use fluorescent probes that can cross the membrane.

label: Multi-cell bolus loading
definition: Method of labeling active neurons with membrane-permeant calcium-indicator fluorescent dyes. Used for monitorization of neuronal ensembles.

label: Impermeable calcium-sensitive dyes imaging
definition: Class of calcium-indicator fluorescent dyes imaging methods that use impermeable dyes, which are injected into neurons either through a recording electrode, or using electroporation.

label: Genetic encoders of calcium imaging
definition: Generic class of methods that use chimeric fluorescent proteins (opsins) that can be used to monitor variations of intracellular calcium concentrations. GECIs consist of a calcium-binding domain (calmodulin or troponin C), fused to one or two fluorescent proteins

label: Single fluorescent protein genetic encoder of calcium imaging
definition: Optogenetic method that uses a single fluorescent protein to visualize intracellular calcium. Usually, the fluorescence sensitivity is increased when the fluorescent protein is split in two (circularly permutation) and its conformation is modulated by calcium bindingdependent changes in the chromophore environment.

label: Two fluorescent proteins genetic encoder of calcium imaging
definition: Optogenetic method that uses two variants of a fluorescent protein modified in such way that their spectral properties allow a specific resonance transfer energy (Forster FRET).

label: acute gene transfer
definition: Class of methods that use viruses for transfer of specific genes into the DNA of the cell of of interest.

label: sampling method
definition: Class of methods used to select few units that will provide the required estimates of a variable of interest for an entire population. Generally, sampling methods are statistic or non-statistic.

label: degeneration method
definition: Class of tract tracing methods that use lesions of myelinated fiber tracts to identify neuroanatomical connections. The lesions of the myelinated axons lead to their degeneration, which is visualized against the background of gray matter.

label: wallerian degeneration
definition: Tract tracing method where the course and terminations of fibers are identified by the anterograde degeneration of the myelin and of distal parts of the lesioned axons.

label: marchi method
definition: Anterograde degeneration tract tracing method where course and termination of neuroanatomical fibers are identified using osmic acid staining of the degenerated myelin.

label: cell reaction method
definition: Retrograde degeneration tract tracing method where the origin of neuroanatomical connections (axons proximal parts and cell bodies) is identified after lesioning the fiber tracts.

label: nauta method
definition: Tract tracing method where the neuroanatomical connections are identified by silver impregnation of the degenerating fibers.

label: Nauta-Gygax method
definition: Variant of the original Nauta method. The impregnated degenerating axons appear black against the background of normal fibers. Also known as the suppresive Nauta-Gygax method, or NautaGygax enhanced silver tracing method.

label: Glees method
definition: Variant of the Nauta method used for identification of the silver stained degenerating axons terminations structures. Can be used in conjuction with electron microscopy.

label: Fink-Heimer method
definition: Variant of the Nauta method that additionally uses potassium permanganate-uranyl nitrate sequence, which allows better visualization of degenerating axons, their terminations, and the terminal boutons (boutons terminaux).

label: anterograde tracing
definition: Class of tract tracing methods that label the axons and their terminations either by anterograde axonal transport or degeneration.

label: retrograde tracing
definition: Class of tract tracing methods that label the origins (cell bodies) of the neuroanatomical connections either by retrograde axonal transport, or by lesions.

label: anterograde and retrograde tract tracing
definition: Class of tract tracing methods that label both the axonal terminations and the cell bodies using both modes of axonal transport or lesions.

label: tritiated amino acids tracing
definition: Anterograde tract tracing method using radioactive amino acids, which are delivered by pressure injection into the region of interest.

label: horseradish peroxidase tracing
definition: Both anterograde and retrograde tract tracing method that uses horseradish peroxidase as stain for axon terminals and neuronal cell bodies, respectively. However, HRP tracing is used mostly retrogradely. The HRP presence is detected using classical immunohistochemistry.

label: radioactive and non-radioactive HRP tracing
definition: Combination of the anterograde tritiated amino acids and of HRP tracing methods, used for visualization of axon colaterals. The radioactive HRP is enzymatically inactive, and the non-radioactive HRP is enzymatically active.

label: retrograde fluorescent tracing
definition: Class of tract tracing methods that use retrogradely transported fluorescent markers. Some of the most commonly used markers are Evans blue, Fast blue, Diamidino Yellow (DI), nuclear yellow, fluorogold (FG). These markers can be used as single tracers, in combinations (e.g., DI and FG), or with toxins-based tracers, and with anterograde tracers.

label: wheat-germ agglutinin and horseradish peroxidase tracing
definition: Combination of WGA and HRP as tract tracer, which can be used both anterogradely and retrogradely.

label: cholera toxin tracing
definition: Class of tracing methods that use bacterial toxins conjugated with HRP, fluorescein, or rhodamine beads. The most used bacterial toxis is non-toxic B fragment of cholera toxin (CTB). The detection is immunohistochemical, therefore this method is more sensitive than HRP. It can be used both anterogradely and retrogradely.

label: micro- and nano-particles retrograde tracing
definition: Class of tracing methods that use small particles composed of a label-coated material, which can be employed alone, or conjugated with other tracers.

label: rhodamine beads tracing
definition: Retrograde tracing method that uses fluorescent rhodamine carrying latex beads

label: gold particles coated with wheat-germ conjugated apoHRP
definition: Retrograde tracing method that combines WGA-HRP with gold particles (10-20 nm). It can be viewed directly through a light microscope and used in EM.

label: diOListic labeling
definition: Neurons labeling method with lipophilic carbocynine dyes that are injected into the cells of interest. These dyes label efficiently the neuron membranes, providing a more accurate view of dendrites and dendritic spines. It can be used in comination with retrograde tracers.

label: retrograde tracing of diOListic neurons
definition: Combination of retrograde tracing methods with micorparticles or fluoorescent tracers (e.g., fluorogold) with the intracellular filling of neurons with lipophilic carbocyanine dyes.

label: anterograde tluorescent tracing
definition: Class of tract tracing methods that use anterogradely transported fluorescent markers. Some of the most commonly used markers are biotinylated dextran amine (BDA), Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL), Lucifer yellow-dextran, fluorescein-dextran, and Fluoro Ruby (tetramethylrhodamine-dextran), neurobiotin, and biocytin. One of the advantages of these markers vs the tritiated amino acids is that the course and terminations of labeled axons can be directly visualized.

label: biotinylated dextran amine tracing
definition: Anterograde tracing method using BDA as a marker. The 10kDA BDA is one of the best markers for anterograde tracing in different species, while the 3kDA BDA is used for cell filling, and for retrograde tracing.

label: phaeolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin tracing
definition: Anterograde tracing method using PHAL as a marker, which is considered the "gold standard" (at least in small animals). PHA-L labels the axons only anterogradely when iontophoretic injections are employed, and there are very few cases of dendrites labeling when the marker was pressure-injected.

label: coinjection tract tracing
definition: Tracing method that involves the injection of two markers in the same injection site. Usually, one anterograde and one retrograde tracer are injected, for simultanerous detection of both inputs and outputs of regions of interest.

label: double coinjection tract tracing
definition: Tracing method that involves injections of two pairs of stains, in two different regions. Each coinjection includes one anterograde and one retrograde tracer. This method is used for unraveling and visualization of networks in regions of interest.

label: transsynaptic tracing
definition: Class of tracing methods that label connections across more than one node.

label: degeneration transsynaptic tracing
definition: Tracing methods based on lesions of tracts that induce degeneration of fibers beyond the first synaptic station (terminal field).
parent class: degeneration method | anterograde tracing | transsynaptic tracing

label: viruses transsynaptic tracing
definition: Tracing methods that use viruses (e.g., PrV and Bartha) as markers, and which label connections beyond the first synaptic station. Viruses that allow transneuronal labeling include Herpes simplex (HSV1) and pseudoraies virus (PRV), and the CSV strain of the rabies virus.
parent class: anterograde and retrograde tract tracing | transsynaptic tracing

label: double-virus translabeling neuron method
definition: Virus transsynaptic tracing method that uses two different viruses to characterize funcitonally related networks. Each virus is genetically modified in such a way that it expresses a specific antigen. The network infected by each virus is identified immunohistochemically, and the common nodes will be doubled labeled.

label: double recombinant viral transsynaptic tracing
definition: Virus transsynaptic tracing method that uses two strains of recombinant rabies virus (RV), each of them modified in such that it will express an unique marker in infected neurons. The RV propagates retrogradely, and if injected in two regions, the network infected by each strain will include the associated marker. The identification of each network is performed histochemically, and the common nodes will be double labeled.

label: golgi-like retrograde labeling using viruses
definition: Cytochemical labeling methods that uses retrograde tracing with retrogradely-propagating viruses followed by the antibody-based detection of the infected neuron.

label: golgi-like retrograde labeling using rabies virus
definition: Golgi-like retrograde labeling method that uses the rabies virus to label a neuron, followed by a specific antibody-based detection of the infected neuron. This method has the advantage of not labeling fibers of passage.

label: golgi-like retrograde labeling using herpes virus
definition: Golgi-like retrograde labeling method that uses the herpes virus to label a neuron, followed by a specific antibody-based detection of the infected neuron.

label: single cell juxtacellular recording-labeling technique
definition: Combination of the intracellular filling method and extracellular electrophysiological method. The pipette is used both for iontophoretic filling of the cell of interest, and as an electrode for monitoring the electrophysiological activity of the neuron. The pipette should be in juxtaposition with the cells' membrane. It can be used for morphological recostruction and electrophysiological monitoring of micromodules made of adjacent neurons.

label: loose-patch-juxtacellular recording
definition: Variant of the single cell juxtacellular recording-labeling technique.

label: bioimaging
definition: General class of non-invasely techniques used to visualize structures inside the body.

label: diffusion magnetic resonance imaging
definition: MRI methods that uses strong magnetic fields to visualize the diffusion process of molecules, mainly water, in biological tissues, The diffusion of magnetically oriented water molecules is influenced by the presence of objects, which interact with the former. Thus, biological structures are visualized by the contrast with the signal given by the spin relaxation of water molecules.

label: diffusion weighted imaging
alternative term: diffusion weighted magnetic resonance imaging assay | DWI
definition: dMRI method that calculates the diffusion rate of water in a location of interest, which is then translated in voxel intensity. Best applied to isotropic volumes, such as the gray matter.

label: diffusion tensor imaging
definition: dMRI method that is used to visualize anisotropic volumes, such as myelinated fiber tracts. The water molecules align with the tracts, i.e., the diffusion along the fibers is higher than across them. Variants and refinements include the generalized diffusion imaging, and the q-space imaging.

label: metals tracing
definition: Tract tracing method based on the transport of metals along axons. Examples include cobalt- nickel- and magnesium-tracing.

label: array tomography
definition: Method used to visualize tens of proteins and peptides in a reconstructed 3D tissue part, together with electron microscopy. A part of interest is fixated in resin, cut in ultrathin slices that are deposited on a single slide, and simultaneously labeled with fluorescently labeled antibodies. The images of all labeled slices are stacked by a fluorescent microscope. After this, the slide can be eluted, and labeled with a different fluorescent antibody.  Finally, after the immunofluorescent analysis, the slices can be imaged by backscatter electron microscopy, and the resulting images are registered with the immunofluorescence images.

label: nucleic acids transfection in xenopus oocytes
definition: This method is used for functional characterization of proteins in a controlled environment. The expression of genes of interest is realized by their DNA or RNA microinjection into oocytes. This method is widely used for characterization of ion channels.

label: single cell multiplex RT-PCR
definition: Multiplex RT-PCR method applied to an individual neuron, which allows identification and semiquantitative measurement of large sets of expressed proteins and peptides mRNAs. It can be combined with whole-cell patch clamp, and with intracellular filling with dyes.

label: anatomical part removal
definition: A surgery method that separates physically (extracts) an organ or a structural part from the body.

label: tissue cutting
definition: Removal of a part of an organ.

label: transversal slicing
alternative term: coronoal slicing | frontal slicing | transversal cutting
definition: Removal of a part of the gray matter along the vertical plane of the brain and spinal cord. The result is a set of slices transversal on the longitudinal plane. Also known as frontal or coronal sectioning.

label: longitudinal slicing
definition: Removal of a part of the gray matter along the horizontal plane of the brain and spinal cord. The result is a set of slices transversal on the vertical or coronal plane. Also known as horizontal sectioning or cutting.

label: sagittal slicing
definition: Removal of a part of the gray matter across the horizontal plane of the brain and spinal cord, lateral to medial.

label: oblique slicing
definition: Removal of a part of the gray matter in a plane oblique to any of the three standard ones.

label: acute slicing
definition: Cutting method specific to electrophysiological measurements and experiments where the fresh brain is kept and cut in a "protective" solution of artificial cerebrospinal fluid.

label: slice mounting
definition: Method used for observation, measurement and long term preservation of brain and spinal cord slices where they are put on a support medium (glass slides or film) and covered by a transparent medium (coverslip).

label: design based stereology
definition: Class of stereological methods that are independent of geometrical features and spatial distributions of objects. Design based stereological methods are created a priori of the measured objects and their properties.

label: model based stereology
definition: Class of stereological methods based on models partially made on a priori knowledge, and partially based on relationships and rules inferred from previous measurements. These methods are likely to hide biased errors.

label: oblique sectioning
definition: Removal of a part of the gray matter across a lane of the brain and spinal cord that makes a nonzero angle with any of the three standard (stereotaxic) planes of cutting.

label: Abercrombie method
definition: Model based stereology method that is used to calculate the average number of cells (points) in a section as the ratio of the product between the number of counted cells and thickness of cells and the sum of the length of cell (in micrometers) and the thickness of a cell.

label: Dellese principle
definition: Model based stereology method where the percentage of the volume of the substance is equal with the percentage of area occupied by the substance in plane sections for a homogeneous object.

label: linear analysis
definition: Model based stereology method where a grid of equally-spaced parallel lines is superimposed on the plane section. The fraction of total length of these grid lines which lie above the phase of interest, is then an approximation to the area fraction.

label: Glagolev-Thomson point-counting method
definition: Model based stereology method where a grid of equally spaced points is superimposed over the section; the number of points that cover the region of interest is an approximation of its area.

label: gray level index method
definition: Design based stereology method proposed by Ziller to approximate the boundaries of a region, based on the gray level index coefficient. It can be addapted to other kinds of tissue classical staining methods.

label: Cavallieri principle
definition: Method of volumes approximation. The volume of any object (brain region of interest) can be estimated without bias from the profile areas of the cut sections of the BROI. The cuts through the BROI have to systematically-random sampled. The volume is approximated as the product of the BROI's sum of the profile areas on all sections with the distance between the sections.

label: unbiased virtual counting spaces
definition: Design-based stereological method used to count neurons in a given volume of tissue using the unbiased virtual counting spaces (optical disector, counting box), consisting of the virtual space within the section thickness and an unbiased counting frame.

label: physical disector method
definition: Design-based stereological method used to count neurons in a given volume of tissue using a disector, and based on the analysis of two focal planes within a thick section (the thickness is taken into account, hence the section is 3D), or of two thin (the thickness of sections is negligible, hence the section is 2D] adjacent sections.

label: fractionator method
definition: Design-based stereological method used to count neurons in a brain region of interest where the total number of neurons is product of the number of neurons counted within all unbiased virtual counting spaces with the reciprocal value of the sampling probability.

label: nuclear method
definition: Design-based stereological method used to estimate mean nuclear volumes of neurons. The midpoint of the nucleolus is selected as sampling unit. The distance from the midpoint of the nucleolus to the nuclear boundary is measured in four mutually orthogonal directions. From the average of the third powers of these measurements an unbiased estimate of the nuclear volume can be obtained. (Gunderson 1988).

label: rotator method
definition: Design-based stereological method used to estimate mean nuclear volumes of neurons where the midpoint of the nucleolus is selected as sampling unit.

label: point sampled intercepts method
definition: Design-based stereological method used to estimate mean nuclear volumes of neurons. In this method, all nuclei of neurons that are found in a focal plane are considered. A set of parallel lines is randomly drawn in the focal plane, and the volume a nucleolus is estimated from the lenghts of the intercept of the test line between its nuclear boundaries. [Gunderson, 1988]

label: Fakir probes
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of surface areas, which is based on counting intersections between the surface and a spatial grid consisting of systematic probes of parallel test lines.

label: isotropic Fakir probes
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of surface areas of thick sections (the thickness of the section is non-negligible, therefore the section is a 3D object]. A set of orthogonal triplets of perpendicular test lines are systematically and randomly placed within thick sections containing the surface of interest. The intersections between the surface and the test lines are counted, and the surface area is calculated from the total number of intersections.

label: Space Balls method
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of the length of fibers. Spheres of hemispheres are systematically and randomly placed in the brain region of interest. The average density of the linear structure (fiber) is obtained from the total number of intersections between the spheres and the fiber. The length of the fiber is estimated as the product between the length density and the estimated volume of the brain region of interest.

label: isotropic virtual planes
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of the length of fibers in thick samples (the thickness is non-negligible, hence the object is 3D). The length of the fiber is evaluated using software-randomized isotropic virtual planes in volume probes, in systematically sampled microscope fields.

label: proportionator method
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of the number of neurons in a given tissue that is similar to the fractionator method, but the sampling procedure is dependent of the neurons sizes.

label: nearest neighbor analysis
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of the cytoarchitecture of a brain region of interest. The method is similar to the nearest-neighbor distance distribution function analysis. This method requires thick sections.

label: Voronoi tesselation
definition: Design-based stereological method used for evaluation of the cytoarchitecture of a brain region of interest. The method first computes the vicinity of a neuron, i.e., a polygon around the neuron, the Voronoi or Dirichlet polygon. This is repeated for each neuron in such way that each of them is included in a polygon, or tile (tesselation), or cell.

label: voltage clamp technique
definition: Class of intracellular electrophysiological techniques where the trans-membrane difference of potential (voltage) is kept constant, and the ion currents are measured.

label: two-electrode voltage clamp technique
definition: Voltage clamp method that uses two intracellular electrodes instead of one, and is preferred for measuring high currents and for larger cells such as oocytes.

label: dual cell voltage clamp technique
definition: Variation of the two-electrode voltage clamp method specifically designed to study kinetics and conductance of gap junctions.

label: single electrode voltage clamp technique
definition: Class of voltage clamp methods where a single intracellular electrod is used for both clamping the cell and for measurement. Used for small cells, or cells that are difficult to get to. Also used for study of plants cells.

label: continuous single electrode voltage clamp method
definition: Single electrode voltage clamp method where both measurement and clamping are performed in the same time.

label: discontinuous single electrode voltage clamp method
definition: Single electrode voltage clamp method where the sharp electrode is rapid switched between the measurement mode and the clamping mode. The cell membrane needs to be enzymatically removed.

label: current clamp technique
definition: Intracellular electrophysiological technique where the current is kept fixed by the experimenter and the voltage is measured.

label: amperometry
definition: Extracellular method used for detection of ions in an aqueous solution, based on electric current or changes in electric current. Also known as pulsed amperometric detection.

label: single potential amperometry
definition: Amperometry method where a direct current is applied into the solution. It is used to detect small currents provided by weak ions. Also known as chronoamperometry.

label: pulsed amperometry
definition: Amperometry method where a working voltage is applied for a short period of time, followed by different potentials designed to clean the electrodes.

label: voltammetry
definition: Extracellular electrophysiological method designed to measure currents when a continuous or variable differential of potential is applied. A small and linearly varying potential is applied between a microelectrode and the medium and the resulting current-potential curve (voltammogram) is recorded. The voltammogram is characteristic of the nature and concentration of electro-oxidizable or reducible materials close to the electrode surface. The cycle can be repetead for smaller or higher values of the applied voltage.

label: electroencephalography
definition: Electrophysiological method designed to measure the electrical activity of the brain at the level of the scalp.

label: electrocortigraphy
definition: Also known as intracranial EEG (iEEG), it is an invasive electrophysiological method designed to measure electrical activity at the level of the surface of cortex. The electrodes are placed directly onto the surface of the cerebral cortex.

label: simple random sampling
definition: Sampling statistical method where all any member of the population is considered to have the same probability of selection. The selection of units is performed by using previously defined randomization procedures.

label: stratified random sampling
definition: Sampling statistical method where the units of the population are distributed over a number of non-overlaping "strata' (the population is partitioned). The members of the population will have the values of the variable used for partitioning much closer one to the other than any unit from a different stratum. The sampling procedure is applied to each stratum. Two most commonly used criteria to divide a population in strata are the spatial location, and sizes of units.

label: systematic sampling
definition: Sampling method that is based on ordering of the population according to a sampling frame. The method usually employs the equi-probability approach where process of choosing the sample units is circular. First, an element is sampled at random, and from here each unit that is a specific distance from the previous (the skip) will be sampled. When this process gets to the end of the list, it restarts from the beginning. This method is applied when the population is logically homogeneous, and only when the population does not has any hidden pattern.

label: cluster sampling
definition: Sampling method where the units are grouped together according to some criteria (clusters) are randomly sampled together and then all measured.

label: multistage sampling
definition: Sampling method where the units are hierarchically organized, and the units are randomly sampled at each level.

label: unequal probability sampling
definition: Sampling method where the probability of a unit being sampled is a function of the characteristics of that unit.

label: adaptive cluster sampling
definition: Sampling method that is similar with cluster sampling, but the sizes (the number of units) of clusters and their number is unknown. In this method, a prior value C is established. If a given unit is higher or equal than C, then the units in its neighborhood are sampled.

label: line transect sampling
definition: Sampling method that is used for objects that are difficult to observe, or are rare. In this method, the observer moves along a line acroos the considered area looking at the right and left and noting each occurence of a given object. Line transects are walked, flown, or traversed, and the perpendicular distances to all detected objects of interest are recorded. Also known as distance sampling.

label: composite sampling
definition: Sampling methods designed for extracting subsamples from initial samples. First, the sampled units are grouped in composite units, and these will be further sampled.

label: clarity method
definition: Neuronal tissue vizualization method where the lipids from the membranes of neurons are eliminated through polymerization and electrophoresis. After this procedure is applied the tissue become translucid, and it can be investigated with sheet microscopy. The tissue preserves the initial form.

label: infusion
definition: Class of methods of administration of substances into the body. Also known as route of administration (medicine).

label: injection
definition: Class of infusion methods that use specific devices for administration of substances directly into the body. These devices (syringes with hollow needles, or pipettes) penetrate the skin of the body, and the substance is delivered mechanically, or using electric currents for micropipettes. Injections can be subdivided by the specific part of the body where the substance needs to be administrated, by the specific device of delivery, and by the mechanism of delivery.

label: pressure injection
definition: Injection method where a substance is delivered mechanically via a syringe or a pipette into the tissue of interest.

label: iontophoretic injection
definition: Injection method where a substance is delivered in the tissue of interest by applying a small and temporary electrical current to the solution in the pipette.

label: nucleic acids and proteins measurement
definition: Class of methods used for identification and measurement of nucleic acids and their products.

label: Fast Blue tracing
definition: Retrograde fluorescent tract tracing method.

label: Evans Blue tracing
definition: Retrograde fluorescent tract tracing method.

label: Diamidino Yellow tracing
definition: Retrograde fluorescent tract tracing method.

label: Fluorogold tracing
definition: Retrograde fluorescent tract tracing method.
